Changes Unknown when pulling **2efe7617a595b8ac6167db40724d9874afd6df23 on francesperry:master** into *\* on apache:master**.

> from my understanding watermark is when the data is actually processed in the pipeline, compare to the timestamp which is when the data has been actually created. It allows us to deal with the skew (the gap between data creation time and data processing time). Correct ? So, in the JMS case, the timestamp is basically the message timestamp and the watermark is when the message is consumed from the broker.

Watermark is a (heuristic) lower bound on all future timestamps (in event time). You are using the message time as the event time, and using the time of the most recent message as the watermark.

If I recall our whiteboard discussion correctly, JMS will deliver messages in timestamp order and in a consistent order even during failures -- so this makes perfect sense: timestamps will only grow, and the last message time is a good watermark.

This is not, however, the processing time. If the pipeline falls behind, JMS timestamps will be well before the processing time. So it is good that you are not using processing time as the watermark!

> the checkpoint is an object holding the last data consumed. It's a kind of unique identifier for the message. In the case of JMS, I'm using the Message ID which is unique and generated by the broker. Correct ?

Again, per our discussion this seems exactly right!

> I implemented the initial split reader using the executor recommendation.

Looks great!

Updates:
- Added javadocs in a few places including the example Jesse suggested.
- Added tests
- Deleted one more piece of unused code
- Properly reduced visibility in the new code

Does the Beam model require that each grouped `KV`/`Iterable` pair be processed as one bundle? If not, I think we need to open/close the write operation not per bundle but per `KV` pair. Otherwise, it could happen that the `Iterables` for all shards are processed as one bundle and we end up with only one written shard.

@rangadi 

I'm surprised we have Kafka `@RunnableOnService` tests. I suspect that they should actually be `@NeedsRunner` tests. Specifically, those tests seem to use mock objects rather than pointing at a Kafka service.
What would be the difference between `@RunnableOnService` and `@NeedsRunner`? The former extends the latter but it seems to be that tests written against one or the other are interchangeable.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/5901985/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/5901985)

Changes Unknown when pulling **2efe7617a595b8ac6167db40724d9874afd6df23 on francesperry:master** into *\* on apache:master**.

### Notes for latest commits:
- Decoupled EvaluationContext from implementation - this allows to keep using existing streaming implementation (until migrated to Dataset API as well) while changing the batch implementation to Datasets.
- Encoders currently using kryo and double casting to easily support generics. Once Encoder API is released (2.1 ?) it'll probably be better to implement Encoders for common Beam Objects such as `WindowedValue` and `KV`.
- Migrated from SparkContext to SparkSession (2.0)
- `Accumulators` (`Aggergator` implementation in Spark) are currently backward-compatible - it'd be nice to upgrade to `AccumulatorV2`.
- Translations for batch transformations to the Dataset API are complete, excluding IOs - this is a WIP, but I'd like to share my thoughts here, I think that implementing `Read.from` as intended in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-17 is possible only with the RDD API, and that's OK (RDD-Dataset are interoperable) and higher-level transformations such as `TextIO` will be implemented as direct translation to `DataFrameReader.text` which provide further optimizations by the Spark engine.
  ~~**_Note: all failing tests are because of the lack of IO transformations support._**~~  
- Concerning `GroupByKey` transformation, since it expects an `Iterable` output value, this implementation materializes the data which might be risky (OOM) but that's the current Beam model as well (which might be better of using `Iterator` instead). All `Combine` implementations (except for `globally`) will use the `combinePerKey` implementation so this will be a problem only if the user insists on grouping by key and applying a transformation to the grouped elements. Maybe this could be optimized as well by holding on to the `KeyValueGroupedDataset` in the context..

Finally, this is a WIP and I plan to work towards resolving IOs first, starting from `Read.from` and moving to higher level IOs. Once the runner supports batch in full, I think we could consider merging with master.
Regarding CI, ASF Jenkins would need some extra configuration; but I guess Travis build wouldn't work until they implement travis-ci/travis-ci#4090.
@dhalperi @rangadi KafkaIO also has a dependency on the `DirectRunner`. Should this be removed and the tests executed in the direct runner similar to the tests in `java sdk` and `core runner`?

runners/flink/runner/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/flink/translation/wrappers/streaming/io/UnboundedFlinkSource.java
runners/flink/runner/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/flink/translation/utils/SerializedPipelineOptions.java
sdks/java/core/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/TextIOTest.java (Comments)

@mxm:
- `@RunnableOnService` means that the pipeline could be executed on any production instance of a runner (e.g., Cloud Dataflow service [hence the name, which is no longer as good], a Spark cluster, a Flink cluster, etc.).
- `@NeedsRunner` means effectively today that a test needs the `DirectRunner` in order to pass. @tgroh is working on the test capability matrix to improve things.

A practical way to distinguish between the former and the latter is usually whether the test requires the the execution happen on the same-machine or even same-JVM -- if so, it's a `@NeedsRunner` test. Conversely, with `@RunnableOnService`, as long as the `TestPipelineOptions` are configured in the right way, the test _can_ be made to pass running anywhere.

Examples of truly `@RunnableOnService` tests:
- tests that do not exercise any external systems. For example, CountingInput.upTo(N) -> Count.globally() -> PAssert(count == N).
- tests that exercise external systems that are hosted publicly. For example, tests that read from or write to Google Cloud Bigtable (see #505) can be run anywhere on the web as long as the execution environment can reach Google's network.
- tests that exercise external systems that are configured using `TestPipelineOptions`. The KafkaIO tests could be written in this way if the Kafka cluster was configured via `TestPipelineOptions` rather than either using mocks or a same-process spun-up Kafka instance.

Thanks Sergio!

@silviulica, @aaltay, what do you think?

> BTW, we should consider adding [WIP] tag to PRs so that Jenkins/Travis won't try to build WIP PRs. Apache Spark works this way and it makes sense.

Uh, that would be awesome. I'll look into it.+
Even without the places that Thomas pointed out, this looks good to me.

Seconding what @dhalperi said; there's also a distinction worth drawing between tests that can be run on a production instance and those which are worth running

Generally, `RunnableOnService` tests should exercise some runner functionality as it relates to the Beam model; `NeedsRunner` tests should exercise some PTransform functionality. As such, not all tests that can be run in production need to be marked `RunnableOnService`
Updated to initialize randomness at runtime and per luke's comments.

Fixed the two Flink cases, which were just unused imports not caught by Checkstyle because it's disabled for that module.

The TextIOTest is just the actual use of the word "preconditions" to mean the concept, not the Guava library ;)
Thanks -- will merge when green.
LGTM, self merge

Thanks Sergio! Any help on doing Maven stuff is more than welcome. We need to keep the tests passing though:
1) setup.py contains a reference to apache_beam.get_version() this will not work since the file itself is responsible to install the apache_beam package. This is the reason the code in there is loading manually the version.py file and executing it. You will need to do something similar.
2) Most tests should start with doing a 'pip install apache_beam...' or more likely 'python setup.py test' on the source code. So we should clarify that in the Maven install section. This is probably what you meant by leaving out the install.
3) keeping the version of a Python package in pom.xml files seems very non-Pythonic to me. If there is precedence for it then so be it but otherwise I would prefer to have it in the version.py file  and perhaps reference it (if possible) in the pom.xml. Or keep it in two places (not-ideal but may fly for a while).
4) Also need to decide on a versioning naming/numbering scheme.
5) setup.py will have to contain the pom.xml as a package data (and get it installed) because the get_version() function is called at runtime.

I suggest as a way to make progress to evolve this CL into  setting up the Maven infrastructure w/o doing changes to the version.py machinery: add the pom.xml file, add setup.py code to install it with the package so get_version() works at runtime, corrections on names.
LGTM, please self-merge
R: @silviulica
LGTM - Thanks Ahmet!

Hi Sergio,

> Regarding CI, ASF Jenkins would need some extra configuration; but I guess Travis build wouldn't work until they implement travis-ci/travis-ci#4090.

Travis should work currently and it is already running Python tests. We do not need the above bug to be fixed. Because python is already installed in every Travis worker image already (https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/ci-environment/#Runtimes) And we also run an apt-get install to install 2.7 version explicitly.

This could be resolved by removing the provided scope on spark dependencies from the Spark runner, but I don't think that's a good idea. Looping in @jbonofre WDYT ? this could make the Spark runner Jar become very heavy.. and what about different Spark distributions on clusters ?

@silviulica, I've tried to address the version issue in the last commits. The new approach consists on reading the version from `pom.xml` during setup, and update `apache_beam.__version__` for later static usage with no other complex operations at runtime.

Thanks @aaltay, I think CI should be fine now with respect to this PR, but still fails because setup issue of the overall python tool suite. We may need to take a look to it with more time.

Regarding the TypeVariable lint error above, I think adding the extra line would be fine.  The TypeVariable('T') object can be defined once at the top of the file and can be reused for all subsequent templated typehint arguments.  It would be a shame to disable the line check globally for this use case.

R: @dhalperi
LGTM and +1 on adding two lines for tpye variable.

Thanks to @dhalperi I now have a better understanding of the requirements:
1. I should not use the AUTO_ACK mode on the JMS Session. Instead, I should use CLIENT_ACK and use the checkpoint mark to store the "pending" messages. Then, in the checkpoint finalize method, I will explicitly send the ACK to the JMS broker.
2. The watermark depends of the use cases and user needs. So, a good improvement would be to use a JMS property where the user can store his actually useful watermark. If this property is not defined in the JMS message, then we can fallback to the JMS timestamp (containing the timestamp when the message has been produced on the JMS broker).
3. Right now, the ConnectionFactory is an attribute of the PTransform (Read). As PTransform can be distributed on the executors, the ConnectionFactory has to be serializable. As the ConnectionFactory is an interface, it's hard to guarantee that any implementation will provide a serializable ConnectionFactory. A potential enhancement would be to use a kind of factory of connection factory, the factory itself would be serializable.

Huge thanks to @dhalperi for his help !
LGTM. I believe that Jenkins is a flaky e2e test, but honestly I think that the flake was not our code. Still investigating, but this can be merged now.
@peihe backport?
